author: djames
msg: [ In branches/ctypes-python-bindings ]
* README: Add some sample output for example.py

author: djames
msg: Update the Txn class to support batch uploads of directories and ignore
lists. Update example.py to take this change into account.
Also implement several other changes, which are tangentally related:
- Refactor upload functions to accept paths instead of file objects,
so as to keep things simple.
- Refactor the Txn class to take advantage of a new "_check_path" function
which calculates the status of a given file, taking into account any
pending operations.
- Update _txn_operation.replay to properly convert repository-relative
URIs into copyfrom URIs.
- Remove an unnecessary root baton open in Txn.commit.
[ In branches/ctypes-python-bindings ]
* csvn/txn.py
(Txn.__init__): Initialize new ignore_func member.
(Txn.ignore, Txn.check_path, Txn._check_path, Txn.upload): New functions.
(Txn.delete, Txn.mkdir, Txn.copy): Update to consider the ignore list,
and to use the new Txn.check_path function.
(Txn.commit): Don't open the root baton as replay already does it.
(Txn._upload_file): Renamed from Txn.put.
(_txn_operation.__init__, _txn_operation._open): Rename contents argument
to local_path.
(txn_operation.replay): Add session argument. Update function to
convert repository-relative URIs into copyfrom URIs using the new
session._abs_copyfrom_path function. Update function to take into
account that the contents variable has been renamed to local_path,
and now represents the pathname to a file on disk.
* csvn/repos.py
(Repos._abs_copyfrom_path): New function.
* csvn/client.py
(ClientSession._abs_copyfrom_path): New function.
(ClientSession.__init__): Save the URL so that _abs_copyfrom_path
can use it.
* example.py:
Update script to take advantage of new csvn features and API changes.

author: djames
msg: Create a new branch for experimental Python bindings based on ctypes.
These new bindings consist of two parts:
1) low-level bindings, which are identical to the Subversion C API
but work from Python
2) high-level bindings, which are easy to use, well-documented and
Pythonic
Fortunately, ctypes ships with a code generator which does a very
good job of generating low-level bindings. We will need to do a
bit of work to integrate this code generator with our build system,
and to allow users to use pregenerated code if the ctypeslib code
generator is not installed. This work should be relatively easy.
The harder, and perhaps more important, task for the Python bindings
is to write some easy to use high level bindings. I've already written
some simple high-level bindings for the Client module, but we will need
to do quite a bit of work to finish them.
This commit was actually performed using the new ctypes bindings, as
a demonstration of how easy it is to use the new bindings.
Branch: ctypes-python-bindings
